My go to breakfast bowl recently because the bananas go ripe I can’t keep up with them. 🍌 I’m always happy to turn them into delicious meals and treats. For you banana lovers, what’s your favorite way to enjoy a ripe banana? . Currently for me, it’s in these banana bread oats. 😌 . Banana Bread Oatmeal 1/3 cup rolled oats 1/2 tbsp ground flaxseed 1 ripe banana, diced or mashed 2 tsp brown sugar 1 cup unsweetened soy milk 1/2 tsp pumpkin pie spice Salt to taste . Add all ingredients to a sauce pan and bring to a simmer. Cook and stir until thickened to desired consistency. I wanted my oats to be thick, so I cooked it to about 6-7 minutes on medium heat while stirring. Just serve with extra banana and extra cinnamon on top. So good. 👌🏽

🌻 Was really in the mood for some rice and beans so while I was on a few calls tonight I baked this thing in the oven. 🌶 It smelled so good! Lots of Latin flavor from the peppers, adobo, sazón and cilantro. Easy and a rice dish you don’t need to babysit on the stove top. 🍚 . Baked Rice and Beans 1 cup uncooked brown rice 1 can black beans, rinsed and drained 1/2 cup tomato sauce 2 cups vegetable broth 1/2 green bell pepper, diced 1/2 red bell pepper, diced 1/2 tsp cumin 1 tsp sazón 1/4 tsp adobo 1/4 tsp black pepper 1 small onion, diced 3 cloves garlic, minced 1 jalapeño, diced Bunch of cilantro with the ends, roughly diced Salt to taste . Preheat oven to 400F. In a sauce pan sauté garlic, add in tomato sauce, veggie broth and all seasonings. Bring to a boil then remove from heat. In a baking dish add black beans and spread over bottom of dish. Layer on peppers, onions and cilantro. Cover with rice and then pour broth mixture overtop. Cover with foil and then place in oven. Bake for at least 55 minutes then remove from oven. Stir with spoon and the. Serve as desired. 🥣

Crispy Baked Tofu 1 block of extra firm tofu, pressed and drained 3 tbsp low sodium soy sauce (gluten free if needed) 2 tsp garlic chili tofu 1/2 tsp garlic powder 1/2 tbsp everything but the bagel seasoning 1 tsp cornstarch 1 tbsp bread crumbs (I used some chickpea bread crumbs I had hiding in the back of my pantry but panko works great too) . In a large Tupperware container, add in soy sauce, garlic sauce, garlic powder, everything but the bagel seasoning and stir together. Add tofu to the container and sprinkle corn starch, bread crumbs, and pinch of salt over top. Seal container and gently toss to coat evenly. Once tofu is coated, spread the individual tofu pieces on a lined baking tray and place in the oven at 400F for 25 minutes or until tofu is crispy on the edges and browned. Remove from oven and allow to cool. 🥣

So I was totally inspired by @veggiekins with this oatmeal after seeing her way of adding turmeric to cocoa powder in beverages. 💕 This oatmeal is chocolatey but has the extra kick of antioxidant nutrition from the added turmeric without making your oats look unappetizing. 🤣 Also major win for chocolate. And I know there is probably a big need for chocolate right now (primarily from me). 😂🍫 . Chocolate Spiced Oats 1/3 cup rolled oats 1 tbsp ground flax seed 1 tbsp cocoa powder 1/2 tsp cinnamon Pinch of ground ginger Pinch of turmeric 1 ripe banana, sliced or mashed Pinch of salt 1 cup unsweetened almond milk 2 tsp sweetener of choice (optional but I recommend) . Add all ingredients to a sauce pan and bring to a simmer. Stir to combine well and allow to cook and thicken for at least 5 minutes. Remove from stove top and allow to sit as your prep your toppings. Stir once more before serving then top as desired. 🤎

Spent this weekend reshooting one of my favorite recipes, bbq seitan from scratch. 👏🏽I actually realized that I didn’t have bbq sauce and didn’t want to risk going to the store again, so made my own along with the seitan. 🔥 I’ll be sharing the makeshift BBQ sauce recipe below just in case. 🥫Paired the leftover seitan with some yakisoba noodles, and sautéed peppers and brussel sprouts. 🍜 . BBQ Baked Seitan 1 cup vital wheat gluten (I used @bobsredmill) 2 tbsp nutritional yeast 1 tsp garlic powder 2 tsp smoked paprika 2 tsp onion powder 1 cup veggie broth 1 tbsp soy sauce 2 tbsp tahini or nut/seed butter of choice (peanut butter works well here too) 1/3 cup BBQ sauce of choice ✨ . Combine all dry ingredients. Add in the wet ingredients except BBQ sauce and give a gentle stir to combine. A dough should begin to form. With your hands gently knees into a dough ball (do not over kneed...this step should just take less than a minute to do). Transfer dough to a lined baking sheet. Flatten and spread dough out until it is inch thick. Then place in a preheated oven at 350F for 25 minutes. Remove from oven and brush both sides with your favorite BBQ sauce. At this stage you can either grill or rebake your seitan. For equipment purposes I went with baking this again for another 10 mins. At the very end of baking to help char ends a little I broiled it on high for 2 minutes. Once removed from the oven. Allow to cook slightly before cutting it into strips as desired. 🌱 . BBQ Sauce 1/2 cup tomato paste 2 tbsp brown sugar 2 tbsp blackstrap molasses 1/2 tsp salt 1 tbsp apple cider vinegar 3/4 cup vegetable broth 2 tsp smoked paprika (if you have some liquid smoke definitely add a splash for extra smoky flavor) 2 tsp garlic powder 1 tsp onion powder . Add ingredients except salt and apple cider vinegar to a sauce pan and bring to a low simmer. Cover with a lid and cook on low heat for 10 minutes. Allow sauce to cool completely then add in salt and apple cider vinegar and stir well. Pour into a container and store in the fridge. 🌻

Spent some time doing some small things that I enjoy. 🦋I spent a little extra time in bed. Got up and baked some more banana bread. Had a warm cup of tea, uninterrupted. And now getting a few simple tasks like cleaning and recipe testing done. Not sure what the week ahead has in store for me, but just going to focus on taking things one thing at a time. 🍞 . Chocolate Chip Walnut Banana Bread 🍫 2 tbsp ground flaxseed 4 tbsp water 3 ripe bananas 1/4 cup natural peanut butter 1 tbsp apple cider vinegar 1 tsp vanilla extract 1/4 cup brown sugar 1/2 tsp ground cardamom or cinnamon 1 tsp baking soda 2 tsp baking powder 2 cups spelt flour** 1/2 tsp salt 1/2 cup walnuts** 1/3 cup chocolate chips . Preheat oven to 350F. In a medium sized mixing bowl combine ground flaxseed and water, stir and let sit for 5 minutes. Once flax seeds gel up, add ripe bananas and with a fork or whisk, mash bananas really well until mostly smooth. Add in peanut butter, apple cider vinegar, cardamom/cinnamon, vanilla and brown sugar and mix well into the banana and flax egg mixture. Add in baking soda and baking powder and whisk together to evenly combine. Add in flour 1/2 cup at a time and mix into batter. Repeat until all of the flour is incorporated. Add walnuts and chocolate chips then fold them into the batter.Batter will be thick, spoon batter into a lightly greased loaf pan and place in the oven. Bake in the over for 50-55 minutes, making sure a toothpick comes out clean. . **I swapped walnuts today for hazelnut. I’m gonna tell you a secret. 🤐I’m not the biggest pasta fan. It’s not that I don’t like it. More so that it’s not my first choice (that is reserved for rice). I’ll mention some of the variations I’ve tried that still came out super amazing and delicious. 🥣 . Smoky Lentil Pasta 2 servings of dry pasta (I used rigatoni) 1/2 cup dry lentils 2 cups veggie broth 2 tsp smoked paprika 1 tsp dry basil 1 tsp oregano 1/2 tsp red pepper flakes 1 tsp garlic powder 1 tbsp tahini OR 1/4 cup full fat coconut milk Or 1/4 cup hummus 1/2 cup pasta water 1/2 6oz can of tomato paste (2.5 tbsp) Handful of greens of choice (I used collards) . In a sauce pan add lentils and veggie broth. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer and cook for 10 minutes on low heat with a lid. In a separate pot cook pasta according to package. For the lentils, remove lid and add tomato paste and all seasonings. Stir to combine and add tahini (or substitution of choice) and greens. Stir once more and simmer for 5 minutes. Once pasta is cooked, reserve 1/2 cup of pasta water and drain the pasta. Add pasta and pasta water to the pan with the lentils. Stir to evenly coat pasta with the sauce. Serve with addition toppings of choice. 🥫

In a container add 2 tbsp low sodium soy sauce, 1/4 tsp garlic powder, 1 tbsp water and 2 tsp maple syrup the. Stir to combine. Add tempeh strips to container and let sit for 30 minutes. 🍌🍞 Everyone must be on the same wavelength because everyone is posting banana bread recipes right now. I had ripe bananas this weekend so I made this amazing chocolate chip walnut banana bread and at this point it’s all gone. 🤣 Enjoyed one of the last slices on top of my oats and such a good decision. 🤤 If you want to bookmark this recipe, I’ve also linked it to my profile for easy access. ❤️ . Chocolate Chip Walnut Banana Bread 🍫 2 tbsp ground flaxseed 4 tbsp water 3 ripe bananas 1/4 cup peanut butter 1 tbsp apple cider vinegar 1 tsp vanilla extract 1/4 cup brown sugar 1/2 tsp ground cardamom or cinnamon 1 tsp baking soda 2 tsp baking powder 2 cups spelt flour 1/2 tsp salt 1/2 cup walnuts 1/3 cup chocolate chips . Preheat oven to 350F. In a medium sized mixing bowl combine ground flaxseed and water, stir and let sit for 5 minutes. Once flax seeds gel up, add ripe bananas and with a fork or whisk, mash bananas really well until mostly smooth. Add in peanut butter, apple cider vinegar, cardamom/cinnamon, vanilla and brown sugar and mix well into the banana and flax egg mixture. Add in baking soda and baking powder and whisk together to evenly combine. Add in flour 1/2 cup at a time and mix into batter. Repeat until all of the flour is incorporated. Add walnuts and chocolate chips then fold them into the batter.Batter will be thick, spoon batter into a lightly greased loaf pan and place in the oven. Bake in the over for 50-55 minutes, making sure a toothpick comes out clean.

Because plantains are my forever staple and just my favorite food next to mango. 😙 If you’ve never used plantains but happen to see them hanging out in the store or you picked some up on a whim, check out 2 quick tutorials for them in my highlights (one for green unripe plantains and the yellow/black ripe variety). I roasted some, made some black beans and roasted corn mix and some sautéed broccoli and drizzled with tahini sauce (just tahini, lemon juice and water—super basic). 🥦 . Black Bean with Fire Roasted Corn 🌽 1 can black beans, rinsed and drained 1/2 cup veggie broth 3 cloves garlic, minced 1/2 tsp garlic powder 1/2 tsp sazon 1 tbsp tomato paste 1/2 cup frozen fire roasted corn or feel free to use canned corn (drain before using) 1/2 small onion, diced . Sauté onion on low medium heat and sauté until softened. Add in garlic and sazón and sauté until fragrant. Add tomato paste, veggie broth and garlic powder and stir to combine. Simmer for 10-15 minutes on low heat. Won’t the back of your cooking spoon, lightly mash beans to thicken them. Add in frozen corn, turn off heat and stir to combine. Allow to sit for 2 minutes then serve. Love this with fresh lime juice, but don’t worry if you do t have on hand. 👏🏽

Needed a serious pick me up today. 😶I wanted matcha oats and that’s what I had. Thank you matcha for having my back during very uncertain times. 🍵💚 . Matcha Latte Oats (updated) 1/2 cup rolled oats 1 cup unsweetened almond milk 1 tbsp ground flax seed 1 banana sliced up or mashed (or 2 tsp sweetener of choice) Pinch of salt to taste 1/2 tsp matcha powder +2 tbsp hot water . In a small bowl add matcha powder. With a spoon or a matcha whisk, gently break up any clumps in the powder. Add 1 tbsp of hot water first and gently whisk/mix together making sure no lumps remain. Add an additional tbsp of water, stir and set aside. Add oats, flax, milk and banana to a sauce pan and bring to a low simmer. Allow to cook and thicken while stirring occasionally for about 5 minutes. Remove oats from heat and add in matcha mixture to oats and fold into oats until matcha is fully incorporated. Adjust salt to taste. 🍵

I needed this bowl so much. 🍛 My favorite pantry meal. I feel like I always have all the ingredients on hand no matter what. Literally have enough of these staples to make this 5 times if needed. 😂 Peanut stew is so good, but I feel that I love the addition of chickpeas and lentils in this to help boost the protein while still enjoying the rich flavor. Filling and super balances. Feel free to leave the greens out or swap for spinach. 🥬 . Chickpea Peanut Stew 1 can chickpea, rinsed and drained 1/2 onion, diced 1 6 oz can tomato paste 1 tbsp minced garlic 1 inch fresh minced ginger or 1 tsp ginger powder 2 tsp smoked paprika 2 tsp cumin 2 cups cubed sweet potato 1/3 cup chunky peanut butter 1/4 cup red lentils 1/4 tsp salt or to taste 3 cups vegetable broth 5 collard leaves, cut into strips . For Instant Pot, add all ingredients except collards to cooking pot. Stir to evenly distribute and seal pressure cooker completely. Set pressure cooker to manual for 10 minutes and allow to pressure to naturally release. Unseal pressure cooker and stir in collard green strips to naturally wilt from the heat of the stew for about 5 minutes. . If cooking on stove top, add onions to a large pot and saute for 3 minutes on medium heat. Add garlic, ginger, cumin and smoked paprika, allowing seasonings to become fragrant (about 2 minutes). Add in chickpeas, lentils and tomato paste and fold into onions and seasonings. Add in vegetable broth and peanut butter, give mixture a good stir to evenly mix. Bring mixture to a boil. Reduce heat back down to a simmer and cover with lid, allowing stew to cook for about 20-30 minutes or until sweet potatoes are cooked all the way through. Turn off heat and add in collard green strips, stirring to incorporate into stew. Season stew to taste and serve with scallions, cilantro and avocado to your liking.

In a pan sauté onion until softened. Add in 2 tbsp of water along with garlic and ginger. Sauté until fragrant, 2 minutes. Crumble in tofu and add soy sauce, sriracha and remaining seasonings. Sauté tofu, breaking it into smaller crumbles in a pan and sautéing to coat evenly with seasoning. Sauté and cook to remove as much moisture from the tofu, about 10 minutes. Coconut Cardamom Pancakes 1 mashed ripe banana 1 tbsp brown sugar 1 flax egg (1 tbsp ground flax + 3 tbsp water mixed together, allow to set for 5 mins) 1 tsp cinnamon 1/4 tsp cardamom 1 tsp baking powder 1/2 tsp baking soda 1/4 tsp salt 1 1/4 cup canned lite coconut milk 3 tbsp coconut flakes 1 tbsp white vinegar 1 cup white whole wheat flour 🥞 . In a medium mixing bowl, add all ingredients except flour and whisk together to evenly mix. Add in flour, and whisk into the wet ingredients, but avoid over mixing. On a preheated griddle or pan (I use a non-stick surface so don’t use oil, but feel free to grease your surface if your cookware tends to stick), ladle 1/4 cup of batter onto cooking surface and spread out as desired. Continue this process until all pancakes are cooked. Makes 8 pancakes. 🥞

Had a lot of random food items that needed to be used up, so in the same bowl they all went. 🤗 That is generally how most of my meals come about. Chickpea Plantain Sheet Pan (makes 2 servings) 1 ripe plantain, peeled and cut into coins (or use sweet potato) 1/2 cup frozen broccoli 1/2 cup chickpeas (cooked/canned—rinse and drain) 1/2 package tempeh, cut into cubes 1 small onion roughly chopped 1 tbsp gochujang or Sriracha 2 tsp soy sauce 2 tsp sugar or maple syrup 2 tbsp water 1 tbsp oil or tahini (I used tahini cause I’m addicted, but just in case you don’t have use oil) 1/4 tsp cornstarch 1/2 small red onion 1/2 tsp ground ginger powder 1/2 tsp garlic powder . Preheat oven to 400F. In a medium bowl, combine everything except plantains, broccoli, chickpeas and tempeh. Whisk together sauce. Add chickpeas and tempeh and toss together to coat. Place chickpeas and tempeh on one section of a lined baking sheet. In the other section add sliced plantain, and in the last section place frozen broccoli. Season broccoli with a pinch of garlic, salt and pepper. Place baking tray in oven and bake for about 25 minutes. Remove from oven and divide ingredients into two separate bowls to serve. Add greens or other veggies as desired. 🥬 . Dressing: Just 1 tbsp tahini, 1/4 tsp adobo seasoning, juice of half a lemon and 2 tbsp water whisked together.

Zoats 1/3 cup rolled oats 1/2 small zucchini, grated (make carrot cake oats by swapping grated carrot) 1/2 tsp pumpkin pie spice 1 ripe banana (mashed or sliced into coins) 1 tsp maple syrup or sweetener of choice 1 cup unsweetened soy milk Pinch of salt . If you don’t like the green bits showing, peel your zucchini before grating. In a sauce pan add all your ingredients and stir to combine. Cook and stir to allow to thicken and fluff up for 5 minutes. Remove from heat and salt to taste or adjust sweetness to preference. For an extra treat sauté some diced apples in a pinch pumpkin pie spice or cinnamon, pinch of salt, 2 tbsp water and 2 tsp maple syrup or sugar. Sauté until apple soften and mixture is absorbed into the apples. Then top over oats. 🍎

Shared a little cooking story of this chickpea tahini stew. 🍛Uses pantry staples and can be customized based on things you might have on hand. Paired this with some chickpea pasta for an extra boost of protein, but this is also something I love to eat with rice as well. There’s just something about a good tomato sauce and rice. 🍚 . Chickpea Tahini Stew 1 can chickpeas 1 15 oz can of crushed tomatoes 4 cloves garlic, minced 1 small onion, diced 1 heaping tbsp of tahini Juice of half a lemon Zest of lemon (optional) 2 tsp dry basil 2 tsp oregano 1 tsp red pepper flakes 1 tsp garlic powder 2 tsp smoked paprika 2 tsp sugar Salt and pepper to taste 1 bunch kale, stems removed and roughly chopped Optional: 2 tbsp nutritional yeast (I didn’t have any so I went without) . In a pan, add onion and sauté with a pinch of salt until onions soften. Add garlic, and sauté until fragrant. Add tomatoes, spices and sauté for 2 minutes. Add tahini and chickpeas (and nutritional yeast of using) and stir to fully combine. Add sugar, stir and cover. Reduce to a low heat and allow to simmer and cook for 10 minutes. Add in kale, stir and recover for an additional 5 minutes. Add in lemon juice and lemon zest. Add salt and pepper to taste and stir well before serving. Serve with chickpea pasta for an extra satisfying protein boost. I used @eatbanza shells and the tahini I use is always @soomfoods because of the creaminess. 🤤

Peanut noodles. 👏🏽 I’m sorry, but also not sorry for using so much peanut butter recently. 🥜 It’s like one of the ingredients out there that just adds so much flavor, easy to have at home and just adds a fun twist to everything. 🙌🏽 As far as I’m concerned, different food items are just a vessel for peanut butter. Apple...peanut butter. Chocolate...peanut butter. Celery...peanut butter. Noodles??? Yes, peanut butter. It’s that food item I never get tired of. So if you’re not tired of it like I am, here are some peanut noodles. 🙈 . Peanut Noodles 1 package of @lotusfoods pad Thai noodles 2 tbsp peanut butter 1 tbsp low sodium soy sauce 2 tsp maple syrup 2 tsp garlic chili sauce 1/4 tsp garlic powder 1/4 tsp ground ginger Juice of half a lime 2-3 tbsp water 1 package worth of baked tofu* 2 cups veggies of choice: I used a mix of shredded purple cabbage, shredded carrots, greens and scallions. . Cook noodles according to package. In a small bowl combine all remaining sauce ingredients and stir to fully combine. Add more water if you want the consistency to be thinner. Set sauce aside. Drain noodles and rinse under cold water. Place noodles back into pan and pour sauce over noodles. Stir to coat noodles evenly. Add in veggies and tofu. Toss to combine and serve. 👏🏽 . Pantry Friendly Ideas: a majority of this meal is pantry friendly. We used noodles for the base. Hearty veggies add a nice texture but will keep longer in your fridge. Think carrots and cabbage. You do not need to include greens if you don’t have that available. If you keep the ends of your spring onion, you can regrow them by placing in a little water (do a google search to find how to do it properly). Peanut butter, soy sauce, garlic chili sauce are all cheap and easy to store. If you don’t have maple syrup, you can swap in equal amount of sugar. I baked some tofu for protein (tossed a block of chopped pressed tofu with 2 tbsp low sodium soy sauce, 1 tbsp sweet chili sauce, 1/4 tsp garlic powder, 1/4 tsp poultry seasoning, pinch of salt. Toss and bake at 400F for 25 minutes). If not tofu available, consider chickpeas or edamame as a replacement. ☀️

Add in broth, stir and bring to a boil. Reduce to a simmer, cover with a lid and allow lentils to cook for at least 30 minutes or when lentils are tender. Remove lid and stir in cilantro. Dinner How To 1 can chickpeas, rinsed and drained 1 tbsp gochujang* 2 tsp soy sauce 2 tsp sugar or maple syrup 1/2 cup water Pinch of cornstarch 1/2 small red onion 1/2 cup sliced mushrooms (optional) 1 inch fresh ginger minced or 1/2 tsp ground ginger powder . Add in gochujang, soy sauce, sweetener, and water and stir to fully combine. Bring to a simmer and allow sauce to reduce for about 5-8 minutes. Add in a pinch of cornstarch and stir. Loving myself for remembering that I had leftovers of this stew. 🍛Today got a bit more busy than I originally thought it would. 😪 So instead of cooking from scratch I pulled out this yummy meal I made two weeks ago. Moroccan Inspired Chickpeas 1 can diced tomatoes 1 can chickpeas 1 cup diced kabocha squash (feel free to use sweet potato) 3 cloves garlic 1 inch fresh ginger, minced 1/4 red onion, diced 2 tsp low sodium soy sauce 1 cup veggie broth 2 tsp store bought Moroccan spice blend (or 1/4 tsp cinnamon, 1/2 tsp Garam Masala, 1/2 tsp chili powder, 1/4 tsp cumin)** Salt and pepper to taste . In a medium pan add onions and sauté until softened. Add in garlic and ginger and sauté until fragrant. Add in kabocha squash, tomatoes, chickpeas and remaining spices. Sauté until fragrant, about 2-3 minutes. Add in soy sauce and veggie broth. Bring to a boil and allow to cook for about 20-25 minutes or until a good majority of the liquid is absorbed. 🌱 . Please note that the spices here do not reflect true authentic Moroccan cuisine, hence why I used inspired. Ginger Tahini Granola 2 cups rolled oats 1/4 cup tahini (make sure it’s runny) 1/4 cup maple syrup (you can use more if you like your granola more sweet) 1 tsp cinnamon 1 tsp ground ginger 2 tsp vanilla extract 1/4 tsp salt or more to taste Optional: add in cacao nibs, pepitas or raisins . Add oats to a large skillet or sauté pan over medium heat. Stir and toast oats for about 1-2 minutes. Add in seasonings and salt and toss to combine then add in remaining ingredients. Lower heat slightly, and continue to stir to prevent granola from burning for about 5-6 minutes. Lower heat again to low and allow to continue toasting while stirring for an additional 3-5 minutes. Granola should have a toasted golden color to them. Remove from heat and allow granola to completely cool before storing. Granola will continue to crisp up as it cools. Feeling very privileged at the moment that I still have my staples in my fridge and pantry to keep me going. 🥣 For today, I made some yakisoba noodles according to the package (@jslfoods) and paired it with some baked tofu and massaged shredded greens and cabbage. Easy Baked Tofu 1 block extra firm tofu, drained and pressed 2 tbsp low sodium soy sauce 2 tsp garlic chili sauce 1/2 tsp cornstarch . Preheat oven to 400F. Cut tofu into cubes and place In a Tupperware container. Add soy sauce and garlic chili. Sprinkle cornstarch over top evenly. Seal the container and gently shake to coat tofu. Take tofu and place individual pieces spread out over a lined sheet pan. Place in oven and bake for at least 20-25 minutes. Remove from oven and allow to cool. Add tofu to dishes as desired. I just folded a serving of tofu into the noodles then served. 🌱 . Replacement Ideas ▪️Feel free to replace the tofu with canned chickpeas. Just drain and coat the same and bake as instructed. ▪️If you don’t have fresh greens, opt for frozen kale/spinach and sauté into the noodles. ▪️Tough vegetation like cabbage will last a bit longer than other greens because it’s much hardier. You can also quick pickle them by sprinkling with salt and a tablespoon of apple cider vinegar, 1 tsp maple syrup and massage with hands. Can be stored and used as needed.

Making the most of these days ahead.🌻If anything, it’s definitely helping me to become creative with my resources. 🙃Got this new @gomacro flavor in the mail to try, Smooth Sanctuary, and it is a combo of double chocolate+peanut butter chips. Smooth Sanctuary Oatmeal Bake 1/3 cup rolled oats 1/2 tbsp ground flaxseed 1/4 tsp baking soda 1/2 tsp baking powder 1 medjool date Pinch of salt 1/2 @gomacro bar, chopped into bite size pieces 1/2 mashed banana or 1/4 cup apple sauce 1/4 cup unsweetened soy milk . Set oven for 350F. In a food processor, add date and oats. Pulse until roughly chopped. Add contents to a single serve oven safe baking dish add add remaining dry ingredients. Add banana and mash into dry ingredients, then add milk. Mix together well. Add in chopped up bar and fold into batter. Place dish into oven and bake for at least 20 minutes or until oats are fully baked. This serves one and can be topped as desired. The bake comes out cake/muffin like. 🌼

Pinto Beans 2 cans pinto beans 2 tbsp tomato paste 1/2 yellow onions, diced 3 cloves garlic, minced 2 tsp smoked paprika 1/2 red bell pepper, diced 1 small sweet potato, peeled and diced 1/2 tsp cumin 1 tsp sazón (I used @eatloisa) 1/2 tsp oregano Juice of one orange 1 jalapeño, minced 2 1/2 cups of veggie broth 2 tsp maple syrup . In a large saucepan, sauté the onions until softened. Add in garlic, sweet potato and bell pepper and sauté until fragrant. Add in pinto beans, tomato paste, seasonings and jalapeño then stir to combine. Add in veggie broth and bring to a boil and reduce to a simmer. Allow to cook for 25-30 minutes, making sure sweet potato is fully cooked. At the end of cooking time add in orange juice and maple syrup and with the back of your spoon, lightly mash some of the pinto beans and stir well to thicken beans. Remove from heat. 🍊

I’ll be very excited once I can cozy up to another bowl of tempeh, Forbidden Rice, carrots, zucchini and broccoli. 😌 Tempeh in general is a fav. I love it’s bitter undertones and I also love the fact that it doesn’t require me to press. Pretty much it’s ready to go out of the package. My favorite way of enjoying it is cut into strips and simmered with veggie broth, soy sauce, a little maple, Sriracha, minced garlic and minced ginger. To help take the edge off, I also like to squeeze a little citrus at the end (lime and orange are personal favs with tempeh). 🥕 . Maple Orange Tempeh 1 block tempeh, cut into strips 1/2 cup veggie broth 2 tbsp soy sauce 1 tbsp maple syrup 1/4 cup water 2 tsp Sriracha 3 cloves garlic, minced 1 inch ginger minced 2 tbsp orange juice (I like fresh) . In a pan, add tempeh and veggie broth. Bring to a low simmer and cover pan with a lid for 3-4 minutes. In a bowl whisk together remaining ingredients except orange juice and set aside. Once tempeh has steamed, remove lid and allow remaining veggie broth to absorb into tempeh at a medium heat. Pour in sauce and with a spatula lightly toss tempeh together to coat in sauce. Allow sauce to thicken and infuse into the tempeh. When tempeh starts to brown around the edges, add orange juice and cook for an additional minute. Remove from pan and serve. 🍊

Happy Registered Dietitian Day to all our fellow health warriors! . 🥦Though these days everyone you meet is a health coach or Nutritionist, some of whom are incredibly knowledgeable, Registered Dietitian Nutritionists (RD/RDNs) are intended to be THE experts on food & nutrition. Our goal is to empower, educate to be your best health advocate & equip with tools to reach your greatest health potential. We seek to help rid the body of disease to enjoy wellness & vitality. . 🥗 To become an RD, one must complete their BS, MS, or PhD in human nutrition. Our undergrad training & science background matches that of physicians & nurses & includes courses in cultural competency, culinary abilities, food/ medication/drug/ herb interactions, food science, & more. After receiving a degree, one must match into an incredibly competitive 2,000+ hour supervised internship (our equivalent of residency), pass an arduous exam upon completion of the program, & as a RD, complete Continuing Medical Education to maintain our licensing & certification. . 🥑As RDs, we wear many hats: physician liaison, counselor, friend, confidant, guide, accountability partner, educator, investigator, chef, & more. We are honored to be part of your healthcare team to help you get well & maintain wellness. . 🍋You may see us in private practice providing counseling & meal guidance, your local grocery stores helping navigate the millions of products, in hospitals figuring out your loved one’s optimal tube feeding formula, your home cooking with you or cleaning out your pantry, through your employer or insurance, or online helping you figure out which foods you or your nursing baby are reacting to. . 🍎Not all RDs are equal. If you’re considering finding one, ask what their area of specialty or focus is to ensure it’s a great match & help you reach YOUR goals! Looking for a RD to help you with your plant based diet? The Academy of Nutrition & Dietetics (USA), National Health Service (UK), Dieticians Association of Australia, & British Dietetic Association, all agree properly planned plant based diets can provide adequate nutrition. Swipe to see some fav RDs & their specialties!

Adobo Stewed Chickpeas 1 can chickpeas, drained and rinsed 1 cup crushed tomatoes 1/2 red onion, diced 1/2 cup mushrooms, optional 1 tbsp tahini 1/2 tsp adobo seasoning (or to taste—I used @eatloisa) 3 cloves garlic 1 tsp oregano 1/4 tsp dry thyme 1 1/2 cups water or veggie broth Juice of half a lemon Handful of hearty veggies of choice (I used asparagus) . Add mushrooms and onions,to a medium pan and sauté until softened. Add in garlic and sauté until fragrant. Add in tomatoes, chickpeas, tahini, adobo, thyme and oregano. Stir to fully combine and allow to cook while stirring for about a minute. Add in water, stir again and bring to a simmer. Allow to cook for about 15 to 20 minutes or until mixture begins to thicken. Allow oats to cook and thicken while stirring occasionally for 5 minutes. Then go ahead and top. 👏🏽 . Place tofu on a baking tray and bake for 15-20 minutes to remove moisture. Remove from oven. In a sauté pan add garlic and ginger and sauté until fragrant. Add sauce and then tofu. Stir to coat and cook allowing sauce to thicken. The serve and enjoy. :)

Meal prep is looking good this week. 👀 Hands up for those meal prepping this week. 🙌🏽 Typically, I don’t prep this many containers at once, but, this is what my travel week is going to look like. To make life as easy and simple as possible, I batch cook a few items, store it in the fridge and prep my container with varying combos through out the week. Here’s a list of the things I will prep typically to get myself ready for the week: . ✅ 1-2 grains or starches (might toast a few sweet potatoes and cook some rice or quinoa in my rice cooker). Let cool and store. . ✅ Cut a lot of veggies/fruits. Pre-chop veggies for easy meals during the week as well as snacking. Get it done once early in the week or chop extra while prepping dinner for the next day. Wait to cut things that oxidize like avocados or squeeze with lemon juice or pack with sliced red onions to keep them from turning brown as quickly. . ✅ Make a few main components. Save time by cooking plant based proteins in the oven on a sheet pan. Section different parts of the pan with different sauces or seasonings (example pesto on half a block chopped tempeh and bbq sauce on the other half). . ✅ Make it a point to make 1 recipe you love to make meal prep more enjoyable and less redundant feeling. Having multiple parts helps. One night you can enjoy almond miso chickpeas with rice, the next day you can stuff it in a sweet potato topped with avocado slices or roll it into a burrito for lunch. 🌯 . These vanilla oats went great with blueberries, kiwi, golden berries and some of my stove top granola. Recipe for the granola is below. 🙂 . Ginger Tahini Granola 2 cups rolled oats 1/4 cup tahini (make sure it’s runny) 1/4 cup maple syrup (you can use more if you like your granola more sweet) 1 tsp cinnamon 1 tsp ground ginger 2 tsp vanilla extract 1/4 tsp salt or more to taste Optional: add in cacao nibs, pepitas or raisins . Add oats to a large skillet or sauté pan over medium heat. Stir and toast oats for about 1-2 minutes. Add in seasonings and salt and toss to combine then add in remaining ingredients. Lower heat slightly, and continue to stir to prevent granola from burning for about 5-6 minutes. Lower heat again to low and allow to continue toasting while stirring for an additional 3-5 minutes. Granola should have a toasted golden color to them. Remove from heat and allow granola to completely cool before storing. Granola will continue to crisp up as it cools. But also really good hot off the stove too.

I have definitely been craving Moroccan spices today as well as a lot of tomatoes, and was so happy with how this came together. Paired these stewed chickpeas with white rice and avocado. 🥑 . Moroccan Chickpeas 1 can diced tomatoes 1 can chickpeas 1 cup diced kabocha squash 3 cloves garlic 1 inch fresh ginger, minced 1/4 red onion, diced 2 tsp low sodium soy sauce 1 cup veggie broth 2 tsp Moroccan spice (or 1/4 tsp cinnamon, 1/2 tsp Garam Masala, 1/2 tsp chili powder, 1/4 tsp cumin) Salt and pepper to taste . In a medium pan add onions and sauté until softened. Add in garlic and ginger and sauté until fragrant. Add in kabocha squash, tomatoes and remaining spices. Sauté until fragrant, about 2-3 minutes. Add in soy sauce and veggie broth. Bring to a boil and allow to cook for about 20-25 minutes or until a good majority of the liquid is absorbed. 🌱

Chickpea Chive Pancakes 1 cup chickpea flour (if not a fan of chickpea flour feel free to use white flour) 1/2 tsp baking powder 2 tsp garlic powder 1 tsp onion powder 1/2 tsp ginger powder 1/4 tsp Chinese five spice 2/3 cup soy milk 1 tbsp soy sauce 1 bunch Chinese chives or scallions . In a small bowl, add all dry ingredients. Add in chives and with a fork, mix with dry mixture. Slowly add in soy milk and soy sauce and with fork mix all ingredients until chives are coated with the thick batter. Take fork and portion a small forkful of the chive batter onto a hot griddle. Spread batter with fork and allow to cook for about 4 minutes until bottom is browned. With a spatula flip pancake. Use spatula to flatten pancake as much as possible. Cook for an additional 4-5 minutes, flattening with spatula to make sure batter is fully cooked and slightly crispy. Remove from heat and serve (makes 8 pancakes; 2 per serving). 😌 . Adobo Chickpeas 1 can chickpeas, rinsed and drained 1 tsp garlic chili sauce 1 tbsp soy sauce 1/2 tsp adobo seasoning (@eatloisa) . Preheat oven to 400F. Take a paper towel and dry off chickpeas. Place chickpeas in a Tupperware container with other ingredients. Cover with a lid and shake well to coat chickpeas. 🍫There are some days where I’m all in for baking and others where I’ll just get as far as mixing the batter and eating most of it before it gets into the oven (I have no shame). 👀 This brownie batter has a bit more nutrition to it like extra fiber without sacrificing the chocolate satisfaction I need sometimes. 💃🏽 . Brownie Batter 1 can black beans, rinsed and drained 1/2 cup rolled or quick oats 1/2 cup almond butter (if you don’t mind pb flavor feel free to opt for peanut butter 👌🏽) 1/3 cup maple syrup 1 tsp vanilla 2 tbsp cocoa powder 1/2 tsp salt 1/4 cup unsweetened soy milk 1/3 cup chocolate chips . Place oats and black beans in a food processor and process on high for 30 seconds, place remaining ingredients except chocolate chips into the food processor and process until thick/smooth (smoothness will be determined by power of food processor). Once smooth, fold in chocolate chips with a spatula. Batter will be slightly warm, so the chocolate will melt slightly. Feel free to allow to fully cool and add more chocolate chips if desired. . This is meant as a fun little dip/spread or something you can absolutely eat by the spoonful (like I did). Really good on toast with sliced banana on top of mashed raspberries. 🤤 . Almond butter can be pricey, feel free to sub for peanut butter (will have more of a Reese’s peanut butter cup taste). To find cheaper jars of almond butter definitely check out the store brand options by Aldi’s, Trader Joe’s and Whole Foods. 💸

Sometimes when we look at processed foods, we automatically assume that it’s all bad. But here are a couple of things to note regarding processed foods: . ➕Not all processed foods are the same. There can be a lot of recipes out on the internet that can make a plant based approach to eating seem super complicated. ✨ If you’re new, focus on the familiar and the easy things. One of my favorite meals I make often doesn’t involve much and can be adjusted based on how simple you want it. See some tips below plus what I actually made: . MEAL: Cooked some @lotusfoods Forbidden Rice using a rice cooker, chopped up some cucumber, used a veggie peeler and made carrot ribbons, thawed some frozen edamame by running it under some warm water, sautéed some broccoli with soy sauce (you can sub for coconut aminos or your fav teriyaki sauce). Topped with avocado, pickled ginger and extra soy sauce. . MAKE IT SIMPLER ➕Use frozen roasted veggies. Brands like Green Giant and even places like Trader Joe’s sell frozen pre-roasted veggies that just need to be reheated (love Trader Joe’s roasted cauliflower and fire roasted corn a lot). . ➕Use easy veggies you don’t have to over prepare (think cherry tomatoes, baby carrots, cucumbers, asparagus, green beans, etc.). . ➕ Pop veggies you want to cook on a sheet pan and focus on classic flavors (garlic, salt, pepper and a little oil if you prefer go a long way). Pop in the oven for 15-20 minutes at 375F. . ➕Use short cuts. It’s okay to microwave things. Don’t let anyone shame you for using frozen or canned veggies/fruits. If you are doing things to help increase your veggie intake, then you are doing a fantastic job. . ➕ Frozen grains are a god send especially if you don’t have time to cook your own from scratch. . I guess my biggest advice is to do the best you can. Everyone’s best is different, and that is okay. If you like making everything from scratch, go for it! I love cooking so it doesn’t bother me. But for people that hate cooking, have to feed more than themselves, are limited in resources...focus on the things you have control over. Be kind to yourself. ❤️

Alright! Like I promised. Here is my baked oatmeal. 🥣One of the reasons I wanted to highlight this is that I know textures can play a big part in people’s enjoyment of food. Blueberry Baked Oatmeal 1/2 cup oats 1 medjool date or 2 tsp maple syrup 1/2 tsp baking powder 1/4 tsp baking soda 2 tbsp walnuts 1/2 tbsp ground flax seed Pinch of salt Pinch of cinnamon 2 tbsp apple sauce or 1/2 a small banana mashed 1/3 cup unsweetened almond milk 2 tbsp blueberries . Good morning! ☀️Thought it might be worth talking about the anatomy of a bowl. 🥣 If you’ve eaten breakfast or any meal for that matter and felt you could eat more, there is a good chance the bowl you consumed is likely not nourishing you the right way. Nourishment can be thought of in the terms of energy, being mentally content with what you consumed, and your mental awareness of your meal. Let’s break it down: . 1️⃣ ENERGY. What’s actually in your bowl? Do you think an instant oatmeal packet for example will sustain you a few hours? See how your body feels with the food you consumed. Ask yourself if you’re good or need to add more. Some people might feel sustained with that packet of oatmeal by itself while others need more rolled oats, some fiber from fresh fruit, some protein from something like soy milk, and/or some healthy fats. . 2️⃣ MENTALLY NOURISHED. If your food is making you feel bad mentally in any form or fashion, it might be time to move on to something else. It’s important to feel good about the food that’s fueling your day. If you feel low energy and crumby after a super sweet treat in the morning compare it to how you feel when you choose foods that sustain you for a longer period of time. It can also be learning more about yourself and learning what foods make you feel your absolute best. . 3️⃣ MINDFULNESS. Do you take time with your food? Not all of us have the privilege to take time with our meals and eat with intention or without distractions. But if there are some small things you can do to insert some balance with your time, definitely take advantage of it. It can be taking a bite and slowly chewing it at least once during a meal, taking five minutes to enjoy the first or last bit of your meal, or even putting your fork down in between bites. I often will have some of my clients work on just looking at their food and appreciate it for what it is. At the end of the day, we can all do the best we can. . Do note that there are circumstances that may make it difficult to participate in some of these actions. They can range from financial difficulty, anxiety, stress, time constraints and much more. Gochujang Spiced Cauliflower Bites 2 tsp gochujang (or sriracha) 2 tbsp tahini (I used the brand @soomfoods) 2 tsp soy sauce or coconut aminos 2 tsp maple syrup 6 tbsp of water 2 cups raw cauliflower, cut into bite size pieces 1/4 cup panko bread crumbs or gluten free bread crumbs (Trader Joe’s has a rice one that’s awesome) . Preheat oven to 400F. Combine all ingredients except cauliflower and bread crumbs in a medium bowl. Mix and you should get a slightly thickened sauce. Add in your cauliflower pieces and toss to coat in your sauce. As you coat, sprinkle bread crumbs over top and toss to evenly distribute over cauliflower pieces. Once all pieces are coated, add cauliflower pieces to lined baking sheet and place in the oven for 20 minutes or until you see pieces become golden on top. Using a fork, carefully flip cauliflower pieces and then bake tray again for 10-15 minutes until you see them get crispy on the ends. Remove from oven and allow to cook for 5 minutes before serving. 🥣 Note: if you cannot handle gluten, feel free to utilize gluten free ramen noodles as a yummy alternative. 🙂
